@Grahame Grieve or @Lloyd McKenzie , can committers just fix typos themselves (in this case myself) and commit, even if the typos are outside of the WG that I'm supposed to commit for? It's becoming very cumbersome for me to open a gForge issue for every single typo I encounter.
I'm not sure. I think that's an FMG thing
in most projects these days it is possible to do a pull-request
this has a much slicker work-flow while retaining some order
I can understand how large numbers committers is a bad idea!
PRs also give some nice tooling around comments/discussion and tracking who has approved them
GF#10212: add date to media posted by david.hay25
@Gaston Fiore You can raise one request that covers multiple typos, but if the artifact has gone to ballot, then there should be a change request that covers every modification - even typos.

GF#10215: Server Conformance size and queries posted by brian_pos

@Erich Schulz

Erich Schulz: in most projects these days it is possible to do a pull-request
Erich Schulz: this has a much slicker work-flow while retaining some order

I can't pass up the opportunity to say I agree: managing a project at FHIR's scale in 2016 without the ability to accept merge requests is crippling. Using git (or mercurial) would enable community participation in a much more natural way, without having to give committer privileges to the whole world. And changes wouldn't be merged if they would lead to a broken build.

Thanks for logging this @Lloyd McKenzie! I added a link to the spreadsheet
When there are conditional ("if...") notes in the "Rationale" column: do we want to make all changes listed in this doc?
Yes - "if going DSTU" means "it's reasonable expect this to be fixed for FMM 1 artifacts, so it's appropriate to be a warning rather than information message"

Some of these changes are straightforward, like:

-      outcome.messages.add(new ValidationMessage(Source.ProfileComparer, IssueType.INFORMATIONAL, path, "Unable to resolve profile "+url+" in profile "+name, IssueSeverity.INFORMATION));
+      outcome.messages.add(new ValidationMessage(Source.ProfileComparer, IssueType.INFORMATIONAL, path, "Unable to resolve profile "+url+" in profile "+name, IssueSeverity.WARNING));

but others have code like:

      suppressedwarning(errors, IssueType.BUSINESSRULE, rd.getName()+".$"+op.getName(), hasOpExample(op.getExamples(), false), "Operation must have an example request");

Is calling warning instead the right thing?
"suppressed warning" is what shows up in the spreadsheet as "information (was warning)". When we're done, there shouldn't be any suppressedwarning calls
yes we want to remove suppressedWarning and make them back to warning
